Signature | [![Appletons' Farragut David Glasgow signature.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Appletons%27_Farragut_David_Glasgow_signature.png/100px-Appletons%27_Farragut_David_Glasgow_signature.png)](/wiki/File:Appletons%27_Farragut_David_Glasgow_signature.png)  
  
**David Glasgow Farragut** [/ˈfærəɡət/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English") (also spelled **Glascoe** ;[1][2][3][4] July 5, 1801 –
August 14, 1870) was a [flag officer](/wiki/Flag_officer "Flag officer") of
the [United States Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") during
the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"). He
was the first [rear admiral](/wiki/Rear_admiral_\(United_States\) "Rear
admiral \(United States\)"), [vice
admiral](/wiki/Vice_admiral_\(United_States\) "Vice admiral \(United
States\)"), and [admiral](/wiki/Admiral_\(United_States\) "Admiral \(United
States\)") in the United States Navy.[5][6] He is remembered for his order at
the [Battle of Mobile Bay](/wiki/Battle_of_Mobile_Bay "Battle of Mobile Bay")
usually paraphrased as "[Damn the torpedoes, full speed
ahead](/wiki/Damn_the_torpedoes,_full_speed_ahead "Damn the torpedoes, full
speed ahead")" in U.S. Navy tradition.[7][8]

Born near [Knoxville, Tennessee](/wiki/Knoxville,_Tennessee "Knoxville,
Tennessee"), Farragut was fostered by naval officer [David
Porter](/wiki/David_Porter_\(naval_officer\) "David Porter \(naval officer\)")
after the death of his mother. Despite his young age, Farragut served in the
[War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812") under the command of his
adoptive father. He received his first command in 1824 and participated in
[anti-piracy operations](/wiki/West_Indies_anti-
piracy_operations_of_the_United_States "West Indies anti-piracy operations of
the United States") in the [Caribbean Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean
Sea"). He served in the [Mexican-American War](/wiki/Mexican-American_War
"Mexican-American War") under the command of [Matthew C.
Perry](/wiki/Matthew_C._Perry "Matthew C. Perry"), participating in the
blockade of [Tuxpan](/wiki/Tuxpan "Tuxpan"). After the war, he oversaw the
construction of the [Mare Island Naval
Shipyard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard "Mare Island Naval Shipyard"), the
first U.S. Navy base established on the [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean
"Pacific Ocean").

Though Farragut resided in [Norfolk, Virginia](/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia
"Norfolk, Virginia") prior to the [Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War
"American Civil War"), he strongly opposed secession and remained loyal to the
Union after the outbreak of the Civil War. Despite some doubts about
Farragut's loyalty, Farragut was assigned command of an attack on the
important Confederate port city of [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans"). After [fighting past](/wiki/Battle_of_Forts_Jackson_and_St._Philip
"Battle of Forts Jackson and St. Philip") Fort St. Philip and Fort Jackson,
Farragut [captured](/wiki/Capture_of_New_Orleans "Capture of New Orleans") New
Orleans in April 1862. He was promoted to rear admiral after the battle and
helped extend Union control up along the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"), participating in the
[Siege of Port Hudson](/wiki/Siege_of_Port_Hudson "Siege of Port Hudson").
With the Union in control of the Mississippi, Farragut led a successful attack
on [Mobile Bay](/wiki/Mobile_Bay "Mobile Bay"), home to the last major
Confederate port on the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of
Mexico"). Farragut was promoted to Admiral following the end of the Civil War
and remained on active duty until his death in 1870.

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Coat_of_Arms_of_David_Farragut.svg/200px-
Coat_of_Arms_of_David_Farragut.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_David_Farragut.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_David_Farragut.svg "Enlarge")

Coat of Arms of David Farragut

Farragut was born in 1801 to [Jordi (George) Farragut](/wiki/Jordi_Farragut
"Jordi Farragut"), a native of [Menorca](/wiki/Menorca "Menorca"), Spain, and
his wife Elizabeth (née Shine, 1765–1808), of North Carolina [Scots-Irish
American](/wiki/Scots-Irish_American "Scots-Irish American") descent, at
Lowe's Ferry on the [Holston River](/wiki/Tennessee_River "Tennessee River")
in Tennessee.[9] It was a few miles southeast of Campbell's Station, near
[Knoxville](/wiki/Knoxville,_Tennessee "Knoxville, Tennessee").[10]

His father operated the ferry and also served as a [cavalry](/wiki/Cavalry
"Cavalry") officer in the Tennessee [militia](/wiki/Militia_\(United_States\)
"Militia \(United States\)").[6] Jordi Farragut, son of Antoni Farragut and
Joana Mesquida, became a Spanish merchant captain from Menorca. He joined the
[American Revolutionary](/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution")
cause after arriving in America in 1766, when he changed his first name to
George.[10] George was a naval lieutenant during the Revolutionary War,
serving first with the [South Carolina Navy](/wiki/South_Carolina_Navy "South
Carolina Navy") then the [Continental Naval](/wiki/Continental_Navy
"Continental Navy") forces. George and Elizabeth had moved west to Tennessee
after his service in the American Revolution.

In 1805, George Farragut accepted a position at the U.S. port of [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"). He traveled there first and his
family followed, in a 1,700-mile (2,700 km) flatboat adventure aided by hired
rivermen, the then four-year-old Farragut's first voyage. The family was still
living in New Orleans when Elizabeth died of [yellow fever](/wiki/Yellow_fever
"Yellow fever"). His father made plans to place the young children with
friends and family who could better care for them.

David's birth name was James. In 1808, after his mother's death, he agreed to
live with [David Porter](/wiki/David_Porter_\(naval_officer\) "David Porter
\(naval officer\)"), a naval officer whose father had been friends with
James's father,[11] as Porter's foster son. In 1812, James adopted the name
"David" in honor of his foster father, with whom he went to sea late in 1810.
David Farragut grew up in a naval family, as the foster brother of future
[Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") admiral, [David
Dixon Porter](/wiki/David_Dixon_Porter "David Dixon Porter"), and
[Commodore](/wiki/Commodore_\(United_States\) "Commodore \(United States\)")
[William D. Porter](/wiki/William_D._Porter "William D. Porter").

## Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/David_Farragut_at_National_Portrait_Gallery_IMG_4516.JPG/220px-
David_Farragut_at_National_Portrait_Gallery_IMG_4516.JPG)](/wiki/File:David_Farragut_at_National_Portrait_Gallery_IMG_4516.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:David_Farragut_at_National_Portrait_Gallery_IMG_4516.JPG
"Enlarge")

Farragut as he appears in the [National Portrait
Gallery](/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery_\(United_States\) "National Portrait
Gallery \(United States\)") in Washington, D.C.

David Farragut's naval career began as a [midshipman](/wiki/Midshipman
"Midshipman") when he was nine years old, and continued for 60 years until his
death at the age of 69. This included service in several wars, most notably
during the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil
War"), where he gained fame for winning several decisive naval battles.

### War of 1812[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: War of 1812")]

Through the influence of his adoptive father, Farragut was commissioned a
midshipman in the United States Navy on December 17, 1810, at the age of
nine.[12][note 1] A [prize master](/wiki/Prize_ship "Prize ship") by the age
of 12, Farragut fought in the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"),
serving under Captain David Porter. While serving aboard [USS
_Essex_](/wiki/USS_Essex_\(1799\) "USS Essex \(1799\)"), Farragut participated
in the [capture of HMS _Alert_](/wiki/USS_Essex_vs_HMS_Alert "USS Essex vs HMS
Alert") on August 13, 1812,[13][14] then helped to establish America's first
naval base and colony in the Pacific, named [Fort
Madison](/wiki/Fort_Madison,_Nuku_Hiva "Fort Madison, Nuku Hiva"), during the
ill-fated [Nuku Hiva Campaign](/wiki/Nuku_Hiva_Campaign "Nuku Hiva Campaign").
At the same time, the Americans battled the hostile tribes on the islands with
the help of their [Te I'i](/wiki/Te_I%27i "Te I'i") allies.

Farragut was 12 years old when, during the War of 1812, he was given the
assignment to bring a ship captured by the _Essex_ safely to port.[15] He was
wounded and captured while serving on the _Essex_ during the
[engagement](/wiki/Battle_of_Valparaiso "Battle of Valparaiso") at [Valparaíso
Bay](/wiki/Valpara%C3%ADso "Valparaíso"), Chile, against the British on March
28, 1814.[16]

### West Indies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: West Indies")]

Farragut was promoted to lieutenant in 1822, during the
[operations](/wiki/West_Indies_Anti-Piracy_Operations_of_the_United_States
"West Indies Anti-Piracy Operations of the United States") against [West
Indian](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies") [pirates](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate"). In
1824, he was placed in command of [USS _Ferret_](/wiki/USS_Ferret_\(1822\)
"USS Ferret \(1822\)"), which was his first command of a U.S. naval
vessel.[17] He served in the [Mosquito Fleet](/wiki/Mosquito_Fleet "Mosquito
Fleet"), a fleet of ships fitted out to fight pirates in the [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"). After learning his old captain,
Commodore Porter, would be commander of the fleet, he asked for, and received,
orders to serve aboard _Greyhound_ , one of the smaller vessels, commanded by
John Porter, brother of David Porter. On February 14, 1823, the fleet set sail
for the West Indies where, for the next six months, they would drive the
pirates off the sea, and rout them from their hiding places in among the
islands.[18] He was executive officer aboard the _Experiment_ during its
campaign in the West Indies fighting pirates.[19]

### Mexican–American
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Mexican–American War")]

In 1847, Farragut, now a [commander](/wiki/Commander_\(United_States\)
"Commander \(United States\)"), took command of the [sloop-of-
war](/wiki/Sloop-of-war "Sloop-of-war") [USS
_Saratoga_](/wiki/USS_Saratoga_\(1842\) "USS Saratoga \(1842\)") when she was
recommissioned at [Norfolk Navy Yard](/wiki/Norfolk_Navy_Yard "Norfolk Navy
Yard") in [Norfolk](/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk, Virginia"),
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"). Assigned to the [Home
Squadron](/wiki/Home_Squadron "Home Squadron") for service in the
[Mexican–American War](/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War "Mexican–American
War"), _Saratoga_ departed Norfolk on March 29, 1847 bound for the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") under Farragut's command and
upon arriving off [Veracruz](/wiki/Veracruz "Veracruz"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico
"Mexico"), on April 26, 1847 reported to the squadron's commander,
[Commodore](/wiki/Commodore_\(United_States\) "Commodore \(United States\)")
[Matthew C. Perry](/wiki/Matthew_C._Perry "Matthew C. Perry"), for duty. On
April 29, Perry ordered Farragut to sail _Saratoga_ 150 [nautical
miles](/wiki/Nautical_mile "Nautical mile") (173 miles; 278 km) to the north
to [blockade](/wiki/Blockade "Blockade") [Tuxpan](/wiki/Tuxpan "Tuxpan"),
where she operated from April 30 to July 12 before Farragut returned to
Veracruz. About two weeks later, Farragut began a round-trip voyage to carry
dispatches to [Tabasco](/wiki/Tabasco "Tabasco"), returning to Veracruz on
August 11, 1847. On September 1, 1847, Farragut and _Saratoga_ returned to
blockade duty off Tuxpan, remaining there for two months despite a [yellow
fever](/wiki/Yellow_fever "Yellow fever") outbreak on board. Farragut then
brought the ship back to Veracruz and, after a month there, got underway for
the [Pensacola Navy Yard](/wiki/Pensacola_Navy_Yard "Pensacola Navy Yard") in
[Pensacola](/wiki/Pensacola,_Florida "Pensacola, Florida"),
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida"), where _Saratoga_ arrived on January 6,
1848, disembarked all of her seriously sick patients at the base hospital, and
replenished her stores. On January 31, 1848, Farragut took the ship out of
Pensacola bound for [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"),
arriving there on February 19. _Saratoga_ was decommissioned there on February
26, 1848.[20]

### Mare Island Navy
Yard[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Mare Island Navy Yard")]

In 1853, [Secretary of the Navy](/wiki/Secretary_of_the_Navy "Secretary of the
Navy") [James C. Dobbin](/wiki/James_C._Dobbin "James C. Dobbin") selected
Commander David G. Farragut to create [Mare Island Navy
Yard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard "Mare Island Naval Shipyard") near San
Francisco in [San Pablo Bay](/wiki/San_Pablo_Bay "San Pablo Bay"). In August
1854, Farragut was called to Washington from his post as assistant inspector
of ordnance at [Norfolk, Virginia](/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk,
Virginia"). President [Franklin Pierce](/wiki/Franklin_Pierce "Franklin
Pierce") congratulated Farragut on his naval career and the task he was to
undertake. On September 16, 1854, Commander Farragut arrived to oversee the
building of the Mare Island Navy Yard at [Vallejo,
California](/wiki/Vallejo,_California "Vallejo, California"), which became the
port for ship repairs on the West Coast. Captain Farragut commissioned Mare
Island on July 16, 1858. Farragut returned to a hero's welcome at Mare Island
on August 11, 1859.[21][22]

### Civil War
service[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Civil War service")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(July 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Admiral_David_G_Farragut.jpg/220px-
Admiral_David_G_Farragut.jpg)](/wiki/File:Admiral_David_G_Farragut.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Admiral_David_G_Farragut.jpg "Enlarge")

Rear Admiral David G. Farragut, c. 1863

Though living in [Norfolk, Virginia](/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk,
Virginia"), prior to the American Civil War, Farragut made it clear to all who
knew him that he regarded secession as [treason](/wiki/Treason "Treason").
Just before the war's outbreak, Farragut moved with his Virginian-born wife to
[Hastings-on-Hudson](/wiki/Hastings-on-Hudson,_New_York "Hastings-on-Hudson,
New York"), a small town just outside New York City.[9][23]

He offered his services to the Union, and was initially given a seat on the
Naval Retirement Board. Offered a command by his foster brother, David Dixon
Porter, for a special assignment, he hesitated upon learning the target might
be Norfolk. As he had friends and relatives living there, he was relieved to
learn the target was changed to his former childhood home of New Orleans. The
navy had some doubts about Farragut's loyalty to the Union because of his
Southern birth as well as that of his wife. Porter argued on his behalf, and
Farragut was accepted for the major role of attacking New Orleans.[23]

Farragut was appointed under secret instructions on February 3, 1862, to
command the [Gulf Blockading Squadron](/wiki/West_Gulf_Blockading_Squadron
"West Gulf Blockading Squadron"), sailing from [Hampton
Roads](/wiki/Hampton_Roads "Hampton Roads") on the screw
[steamer](/wiki/Steamship "Steamship") [USS
_Hartford_](/wiki/USS_Hartford_\(1858\) "USS Hartford \(1858\)"), bearing 25
guns, which he made his [flagship](/wiki/Flagship "Flagship"), accompanied by
a fleet of 17 ships. He reached the mouth of the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"), near Confederate forts
[St. Philip](/wiki/Fort_St._Philip "Fort St. Philip") and
[Jackson](/wiki/Fort_Jackson,_Louisiana "Fort Jackson, Louisiana"), situated
opposite one another along the banks of the river, with a combined armament of
more than 100 heavy guns and a complement of 700 men. Now aware of Farragut's
approach, the Confederates had amassed a fleet of 16 gunboats just outside New
Orleans.[24]

On April 18, Farragut ordered the mortar boats, under the command of Porter,
to commence bombardment on the two forts, inflicting considerable damage, but
not enough to compel the Confederates into surrender. After two days of [heavy
bombardment](/wiki/Battle_of_Forts_Jackson_and_St._Philip "Battle of Forts
Jackson and St. Philip"), Farragut ran past forts Jackson and St. Philip and
the [Chalmette](/wiki/Chalmette,_Louisiana "Chalmette, Louisiana") batteries
to take the city and port of [New
Orleans](/wiki/Battle_of_New_Orleans_\(Civil_War\) "Battle of New Orleans
\(Civil War\)") on April 29, a decisive event in the war.[25]

Congress honored him by creating the rank of [rear
admiral](/wiki/Rear_admiral_\(United_States\) "Rear admiral \(United
States\)") on July 16, 1862, a rank never before used in the U.S. Navy. Before
this time, the American Navy had resisted the rank of admiral, preferring the
term "flag officer", to distinguish the rank from the traditions of the
European navies.

Later that year, Farragut passed the batteries defending [Vicksburg,
Mississippi](/wiki/Vicksburg,_Mississippi "Vicksburg, Mississippi"), but had
no success there. A makeshift [Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_Navy
"Confederate States Navy") [ironclad](/wiki/Ironclad "Ironclad") forced his
flotilla of 38 ships to withdraw in July 1862.

While an aggressive commander, Farragut was not always cooperative. At the
[Siege of Port Hudson](/wiki/Siege_of_Port_Hudson "Siege of Port Hudson"), the
plan was that Farragut's flotilla would pass by the guns of the
[Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America") stronghold with the help of a diversionary land attack by the [Army
of the Gulf](/wiki/Army_of_the_Gulf "Army of the Gulf"), commanded by General
[Nathaniel Banks](/wiki/Nathaniel_Banks "Nathaniel Banks"), to commence at
8:00 a.m. on March 15, 1863. Farragut unilaterally decided to move the
timetable up to 9:00 p.m. on March 14, and initiated his run past the guns
before Union ground forces were in position. The consequently uncoordinated
attack allowed the Confederates to concentrate on Farragut's flotilla and
inflict heavy damage to his warships.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/DavidFarragutonUSSHartford.jpg/220px-
DavidFarragutonUSSHartford.jpg)](/wiki/File:DavidFarragutonUSSHartford.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DavidFarragutonUSSHartford.jpg "Enlarge")

Farragut on board _Hartford_

Farragut's battle group was forced to retreat with only two ships able to pass
the heavy cannon of the Confederate bastion. After surviving the gauntlet,
Farragut played no further part in the battle for [Port
Hudson](/wiki/Port_Hudson,_Louisiana "Port Hudson, Louisiana"), and General
Banks was left to continue the siege without the advantage of naval support.
The [Union Army](/wiki/Union_Army "Union Army") made two major attacks on the
fort; both were repulsed with heavy losses. Farragut's flotilla was
splintered, yet was able to blockade the mouth of the [Red
River](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_South "Red River of the South") with the two
remaining warships; he could not efficiently patrol the section of the
Mississippi between Port Hudson and Vicksburg. Farragut's decision proved
costly to the Union Navy and the Union Army, which suffered its highest
casualty rate of the war at Port Hudson.

[Vicksburg surrendered](/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg") on July
4, 1863, leaving Port Hudson as the last remaining Confederate stronghold on
the Mississippi River. General Banks accepted the surrender of the Confederate
garrison at Port Hudson on July 9, ending the longest siege in U.S. military
history. [Control of the Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River_campaigns_in_the_American_Civil_War
"Mississippi River campaigns in the American Civil War") was the centerpiece
of the Union strategy to win the war, and, with the surrender of Port Hudson,
the Confederacy was now cut in two.

On August 5, 1864, Farragut won a great victory in the [Battle of Mobile
Bay](/wiki/Battle_of_Mobile_Bay "Battle of Mobile Bay"). [Mobile,
Alabama](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama "Mobile, Alabama"), was then the Confederacy's
last major open port on the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of
Mexico"). The bay was heavily mined (tethered [naval mines](/wiki/Naval_mine
"Naval mine") were then known as "torpedoes").[26] Farragut ordered his fleet
to charge the bay. When the monitor [USS
_Tecumseh_](/wiki/USS_Tecumseh_\(1863\) "USS Tecumseh \(1863\)") struck a mine
and sank, the others began to pull back.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Farragut%26Granger.jpg/220px-
Farragut%26Granger.jpg)](/wiki/File:Farragut%26Granger.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Farragut%26Granger.jpg "Enlarge")

Admiral David Farragut and General Gordon Granger

Farragut could see the ships pulling back from his high perch, where he was
lashed to the rigging of his flagship, USS _Hartford_. "What's the trouble?",
he shouted through a trumpet to [USS _Brooklyn_](/wiki/USS_Brooklyn_\(1858\)
"USS Brooklyn \(1858\)"). "Torpedoes", was the shouted reply. "Damn the
torpedoes.", said Farragut, "Four bells, [Captain
Drayton](/wiki/Percival_Drayton "Percival Drayton"), go ahead.
[Jouett](/wiki/James_Edward_Jouett "James Edward Jouett"), full
speed."[27][28] The bulk of the fleet succeeded in entering the bay. Farragut
triumphed over the opposition of heavy batteries in [Fort
Morgan](/wiki/Fort_Morgan_\(Alabama\) "Fort Morgan \(Alabama\)") and [Fort
Gaines](/wiki/Fort_Gaines_\(Alabama\) "Fort Gaines \(Alabama\)") to defeat the
squadron of Admiral [Franklin Buchanan](/wiki/Franklin_Buchanan "Franklin
Buchanan").

On December 21, 1864, Lincoln promoted Farragut to vice admiral.

### Post-Civil War
service[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Post-Civil War service")]

After the Civil War, Farragut was elected a companion of the first class of
the New York Commandery of the [Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the
United States](/wiki/Military_Order_of_the_Loyal_Legion_of_the_United_States
"Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States") on March 18, 1866
and assigned insignia number 231. He served as the commander of the Commandery
of New York from May 1866 to until his death.

Farragut was promoted to full [admiral](/wiki/Admiral_\(United_States\)
"Admiral \(United States\)") on July 25, 1866, becoming the first U.S. Naval
officer to hold that rank.[6]

His last active service was in command of the [European
Squadron](/wiki/European_Squadron "European Squadron"), from 1867 to 1868,
with the [screw frigate](/wiki/Screw_frigate "Screw frigate") [USS
_Franklin_](/wiki/USS_Franklin_\(1864\) "USS Franklin \(1864\)") as his
[flagship](/wiki/Flagship "Flagship"). Farragut remained on active duty for
life, an honor accorded to only seven other U.S. Naval officers after the
Civil War.[29]

## Death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Death")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Admiral_David_Farragut_Monument_1024.jpg/220px-
Admiral_David_Farragut_Monument_1024.jpg)](/wiki/File:Admiral_David_Farragut_Monument_1024.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Admiral_David_Farragut_Monument_1024.jpg "Enlarge")

The monument of Admiral David Farragut in [Woodlawn
Cemetery](/wiki/Woodlawn_Cemetery_\(Bronx,_New_York\) "Woodlawn Cemetery
\(Bronx, New York\)") in [The Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx "The Bronx"), [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").

Admiral Farragut died from a heart attack at the age of 69 in [Portsmouth, New
Hampshire](/wiki/Portsmouth,_New_Hampshire "Portsmouth, New Hampshire"), while
on vacation in the late summer of 1870. He had served almost sixty years in
the navy. He is interred at [Woodlawn Cemetery](/wiki/Woodlawn_Cemetery,_Bronx
"Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx"), in [The Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx "The Bronx"), [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[30] His
[gravesite](/wiki/Admiral_David_Glasgow_Farragut_Gravesite "Admiral David
Glasgow Farragut Gravesite") is listed on the [National Register of Historic
Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of
Historic Places"), as is Woodlawn Cemetery itself.

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Personal life")]

After appointment and an initial cruise as acting lieutenant commanding [USS
_Ferret_](/wiki/USS_Ferret_\(1822\) "USS Ferret \(1822\)"), Farragut married
Susan Caroline Marchant on September 2, 1824.[31] After years of ill-health,
Susan Farragut died on December 27, 1840. Farragut was noted for his kindly
treatment of his wife during her illness.[32]

After the death of his first wife, Farragut married Virginia Dorcas Loyall, on
December 26, 1843, with whom he had one surviving son, named Loyall Farragut,
born October 12, 1844. Loyall Farragut graduated from [West
Point](/wiki/West_Point "West Point") in 1868, and served as a [second
lieutenant](/wiki/Second_lieutenant "Second lieutenant") in the [US
Army](/wiki/US_Army "US Army") before resigning in 1872. He spent most of the
remainder of his career as an executive with the Central Railroad Company of
New Jersey. He died in 1916.[33]

## Timeline of
service[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Timeline of service")]

  * December 17, 1810, appointed midshipman.
  * 1812, assigned to the [USS _Essex_](/wiki/USS_Essex_\(1799\) "USS Essex \(1799\)").
  * 1815–1817, served in the [Mediterranean Sea](/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea "Mediterranean Sea") aboard the _Independence_ and the _Macedonian_.
  * 1818, studied ashore for nine months at [Tunis](/wiki/Tunis "Tunis").
  * 1819, served as a lieutenant on the [USS _Shark_](/wiki/USS_Shark_\(1821\) "USS Shark \(1821\)").
  * 1823, placed in command of the [USS _Ferret_](/wiki/USS_Ferret_\(1822\) "USS Ferret \(1822\)").
  * January 10, 1825, promoted to lieutenant on the frigate _Brandywine_.
  * 1826–1838, served in subordinate capacities on various vessels.
  * 1838, placed in command of the sloop _Erie_.
  * September 8, 1841, promoted to the rank of commander.
  * [Mexican–American War](/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War "Mexican–American War"), commanded the sloop of war, _Saratoga_.
  * 1848–1853, duty at [Norfolk, Navy Yard](/wiki/Norfolk_Navy_Base "Norfolk Navy Base") in [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") as Assistant Inspector of Ordinance.
  * September 1852 – August 1853, assigned to superintend the testing of the endurance of naval gun batteries at [Old Point Comfort](/wiki/Old_Point_Comfort "Old Point Comfort") at [Fort Monroe](/wiki/Fort_Monroe "Fort Monroe") in [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia").[34]
  * 1853–1854, duty at Washington, D.C.
  * September 14, 1855, promoted to the rank of captain.
  * 1854–1858, duty establishing [Mare Island Navy Yard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Navy_Yard "Mare Island Navy Yard") at [San Francisco Bay](/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay "San Francisco Bay").
  * 1858–1859, commander of the sloop of war USS _Brooklyn_.
  * 1860–1861, stationed at Norfolk Navy Yard.
  * January 1862, commanded USS _Hartford_ and the [West Gulf blockading squadron](/wiki/Union_blockade "Union blockade") of 17 vessels.
  * April 1862, took command of occupied [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans").
  * July 16, 1862, promoted to rear admiral.
  * June 23, 1862, wounded near Vicksburg, Mississippi.
  * May 1863, commanded USS _Monongahela_.
  * May 1863, commanded the USS _Pensacola_.
  * July 1863, commanded USS _Tennessee_.
  * August 5, 1864, Battle of Mobile Bay
  * September 5, 1864, offered command of the [North Atlantic Blocking Squadron](/wiki/Union_blockade "Union blockade"), but he declined because of family issues.
  * December 21, 1864, promoted to vice admiral.
  * April 1865, [pallbearer](/wiki/Pallbearer "Pallbearer") for the funeral of [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln").
  * July 25, 1866, promoted to admiral.
  * June 1867, commanded USS _Franklin_.
  * 1867–1868, commanded European Squadron.

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Farragut&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Legacy")]

The area formerly known as Campbell's Station, Tennessee, only a few miles
from Admiral Farragut's birthplace, was renamed as the town of
[Farragut](/wiki/Farragut,_Tennessee "Farragut, Tennessee") in his honor.

[Farragut Square](/wiki/Farragut_Square "Farragut Square") in Washington, D.C.
is named in his honor. A statue of him, named _[Admiral David G.
Farragut](/wiki/Admiral_David_G._Farragut_\(Ream_statue\) "Admiral David G.
Farragut \(Ream statue\)")_ , is in the center of Farragut Square. Two
[Washington Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro") stations,
[Farragut West](/wiki/Farragut_West_station "Farragut West station") and
[Farragut North](/wiki/Farragut_North_station "Farragut North station"), also
share his name. There is a statue of Admiral Farragut at the [South
Boston](/wiki/South_Boston "South Boston") Marine Park adjacent to [Castle
Island](/wiki/Castle_Island_\(Massachusetts\) "Castle Island
\(Massachusetts\)"), and an [outdoor sculpture of
him](/wiki/Admiral_David_Glasgow_Farragut_\(Manhattan\) "Admiral David Glasgow
Farragut \(Manhattan\)") in [Madison Square Park](/wiki/Madison_Square_Park
"Madison Square Park"), Manhattan.

Two separate [classes](/wiki/Ship_class "Ship class") of U.S. Navy
[destroyers](/wiki/Destroyers "Destroyers") have been named for Farragut: the
[_Farragut_ class of 1934](/wiki/Farragut-class_destroyer_\(1934\) "Farragut-
class destroyer \(1934\)") and the [_Farragut_ class of 1958](/wiki/Farragut-
class_destroyer_\(1958\) "Farragut-class destroyer \(1958\)"). Several
individual U.S. Navy ships also have been named [USS
_Farragut_](/wiki/USS_Farragut "USS Farragut") in his honor.

Few naval officers in American history have been honored on a U.S. postage
stamp, but David Farragut has been so honored more than once. The first
postage stamp (at left) to honor Farragut was the 1-dollar black [issue of
1903](/wiki/Series_of_1902 "Series of 1902"). The Navy Issue of 1937 includes
(among five in a series) a 3-cent purple stamp which depicts Admirals David
Farragut (left) and [David Porter](/wiki/David_Dixon_Porter "David Dixon
Porter"), with a warship under sail displayed at center. The most recent
postage issue honoring Farragut was released from Gettysburg, Pennsylvania on
June 29, 1995.[35][36]

Numerous places and things are named in remembrance of Admiral Farragut:

  * [Admiral Farragut Academy](/wiki/Admiral_Farragut_Academy "Admiral Farragut Academy") is a college [preparatory school](/wiki/University-preparatory_school "University-preparatory school") with naval training founded in 1933 by navy admirals in [Pine Beach, New Jersey](/wiki/Pine_Beach,_New_Jersey "Pine Beach, New Jersey"). In 1945 the current and now only campus opened in [St. Petersburg, Florida](/wiki/St._Petersburg,_Florida "St. Petersburg, Florida"). In 1946 it was designated by Congress as a Naval Honor School.[37]
  * [Farragut, Tennessee](/wiki/Farragut,_Tennessee "Farragut, Tennessee"), Admiral Farragut's hometown of Campbell's Station (see [Battle of Campbell's Station](/wiki/Battle_of_Campbell%27s_Station "Battle of Campbell's Station")), Tennessee, was renamed Farragut when it became incorporated in 1982. Admiral Farragut was actually born at Lowe's Ferry on the Holston (now Tennessee) River a few miles southeast of the town, but at that time Campbell's Station was the nearest settlement.
  * [Farragut Square](/wiki/Farragut_Square "Farragut Square") in Washington, D.C. is named in his honor.
  * [Farragut High School](/wiki/Farragut_High_School "Farragut High School") was built at Admiral Farragut's home town of Campbell's Station (now Farragut) in 1904. Today Farragut High School, boasting nearly 2,500 students, is one of the largest schools in Tennessee. The school's colors are blue and white, and its sporting teams are known as "The Admirals".
  * [Farragut](/wiki/Farragut,_Brooklyn "Farragut, Brooklyn"), a neighborhood in Brooklyn
  * Farragut Field is a sports field at the [United States Naval Academy](/wiki/United_States_Naval_Academy "United States Naval Academy").
  * [Farragut Career Academy](/wiki/Farragut_Career_Academy "Farragut Career Academy") in Chicago, [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") is a high school in the Chicago Public Schools system that was founded in 1894; its sporting teams are also known as the Admirals. The school displays an oil painting of the admiral, presented to the school by the Farragut Post of the [Grand Army of the Republic](/wiki/Grand_Army_of_the_Republic "Grand Army of the Republic") in 1896. [NBA](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association") star [Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett") attended Farragut Career Academy. Wheel of Fortune host Pat Sajak is also a prominent alum.
  * [Farragut, Iowa](/wiki/Farragut,_Iowa "Farragut, Iowa") is a small farming town in southwestern Iowa. Admiral Farragut's famous slogan greets visitors from a billboard on the edge of town. The local school, Farragut Community High School, fields varsity "Admiral" and JV "Sailor" teams. The school also houses memorabilia from the ships that have borne the Farragut name.
  * Five U.S. Navy [destroyers](/wiki/Destroyer "Destroyer") have been named [USS _Farragut_](/wiki/USS_Farragut "USS Farragut"), including two [class leaders](/wiki/Class_leader "Class leader").
  * In World War II, the United States [liberty ship](/wiki/Liberty_ship "Liberty ship") [SS _David G. Farragut_](/w/index.php?title=SS_David_G._Farragut&action=edit&redlink=1 "SS David G. Farragut \(page does not exist\)") was named in his honor.
  * [Farragut Square](/wiki/Farragut_Square "Farragut Square"), a park in Washington, D.C.; the square lends its name to two nearby [Metro](/wiki/Washington_Metro "Washington Metro") stations: [Farragut North](/wiki/Farragut_North_\(Washington_Metro\) "Farragut North \(Washington Metro\)") and [Farragut West](/wiki/Farragut_West_\(Washington_Metro\) "Farragut West \(Washington Metro\)").
  * Three U.S. [postage stamps](/wiki/Postage_stamps_and_postal_history_of_the_United_States "Postage stamps and postal history of the United States"): the $1 stamp of 1903, the $0.03 stamp with Admiral David Porter in 1937 and a $0.32 stamp in 1995.
  * 100-dollar Treasury notes, also called coin notes, of the Series 1890 and 1891, feature portraits of Farragut on the obverse. The 1890 Series note is called a $100 Watermelon Note by collectors, because the large zeroes on the reverse resemble the pattern on a [watermelon](/wiki/Watermelon "Watermelon").
  * A stained glass window in the United States Naval Academy Chapel depicts Farragut in the rigging of _USS Hartford_ at Mobile Bay.
  * [David Glasgow Farragut High School](/wiki/David_Glasgow_Farragut_High_School "David Glasgow Farragut High School") is the [U.S. Department of Defense](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Defense "U.S. Department of Defense") High School located on the [Naval Station](/wiki/Naval_Station_Rota,_Spain "Naval Station Rota, Spain") in [Rota](/wiki/Rota,_Spain "Rota, Spain"), Spain. Their sporting teams are also known as "The Admirals".
  * Farragut Parkway in [Hastings-on-Hudson, New York](/wiki/Hastings-on-Hudson,_New_York "Hastings-on-Hudson, New York").
  * Farragut Middle School in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.
  * [David Farragut School](/wiki/David_Farragut_School_\(Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania\) "David Farragut School \(Philadelphia, Pennsylvania\)") in Philadelphia
  * A grade school in [Mayagüez, Puerto Rico](/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez,_Puerto_Rico "Mayagüez, Puerto Rico").
  * A grade school (PS 44) in [the Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx "The Bronx").
  * [Farragut State Park](/wiki/Farragut_State_Park "Farragut State Park") in [Idaho](/wiki/Idaho "Idaho"), which was used as a naval base for basic training during World War II.
  * A hotel in [Menorca](/wiki/Menorca "Menorca") at Cala'n Forcat.
  * A bust in full naval regalia on the top floor of the [Tennessee State Capitol](/wiki/Tennessee_State_Capitol "Tennessee State Capitol").
  * Admiral Farragut condominium on waterway in [Coral Gables, Florida](/wiki/Coral_Gables,_Florida "Coral Gables, Florida").
  * Farragut elementary school in Vallejo Ca. Located just outside the Mare Island Gate.
  * A monument is located off Northshore Drive in [Concord, Tennessee](/wiki/Concord,_Tennessee "Concord, Tennessee"). The monument reads "BIRTHPLACE OF ADMIRAL FARRAGUT/BORN JULY 5, 1801 . . . DEDICATED BY [ADMIRAL DEWEY](/wiki/George_Dewey "George Dewey"), MAY 15, 1900".[38]
  * The [David Farragut School](/wiki/David_Farragut_School,_Boston,_Massachusetts "David Farragut School, Boston, Massachusetts") is an elementary school in Boston, Massachusetts
  * The Farragut House bar–restaurant located in [South Boston](/wiki/South_Boston,_Massachusetts "South Boston, Massachusetts"), [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts "Massachusetts").
  * A larger than life statue near the beach in South Boston.

  * Farragut Inn at [Touro University California](/wiki/Touro_University_California "Touro University California") located on the [Mare Island Naval Shipyard](/wiki/Mare_Island_Naval_Shipyard "Mare Island Naval Shipyard").

[June Dayton](/wiki/June_Dayton "June Dayton") was cast in the episode as Farragut's second wife, Virginia.
  * Farragut is mentioned in _[The Wild Wild West](/wiki/The_Wild_Wild_West "The Wild Wild West")_ episode "The Night of the Kraken", although he does not appear. At the climax, the story's villains try to destroy Farragut's ship with a [naval mine](/wiki/Naval_mine "Naval mine"), but are foiled by the series' heroes.
